SMALBERGER JA:
On 18 May 1992 Bercon Mining (Pty) Limited
("Bercon"), a company carrying on mining activities, addressed a letter
to the appellant ("Grand Mines"), the owner of a colliery, the relevant
portions of which read:
"OPENCAST PIT MINING AT YOUR
NORTHFIELD
COLLIERY - BRONKHORSTSPRUIT
We thank you for the opportunity to tender for the
abovementioned contract and submit our offer as follows:
1.
RATE
:
The rate is R14,00 per R.O.M. ton delivered
to stockpile at your screening plant on the
mine.
The above rate was calculated as follows:
a)
Ratio of not more than 2:1 (2M3
overburden to 1 ton of coal).
b)
Drill and blast of not more than 50% of
overburden.
The above rate includes:
1) Removal of hard and soft overburden to
reclaim area.
3

sections.facts: Grand Mines owned the Northfield Colliery and sought to engage Bercon Mining (Pty) Limited to carry out open‑cast pit mining. On 18 May 1992 Bercon sent a letter to Grand Mines proposing a rate of R14.00 per ROM ton delivered to a stockpile, with details on overburden ratios and drilling requirements. A dispute later arose concerning the formation, interpretation and enforceability of the proposed contract and the agreed rate.
sections.issues: The key issues were whether the letter constituted a legally binding offer that was accepted by Grand Mines, thereby forming a contract, and, if so, what the correct rate and obligations of the parties were under that contract.
sections.principles: The court applied South African contract law principles, focusing on the requirements for a valid offer, clear acceptance, consideration, and the rules for interpreting contractual terms. It also considered the doctrine of estoppel where conduct may imply acceptance.
sections.application: Analyzing the correspondence, the court assessed whether Grand Mines’ conduct demonstrated unequivocal acceptance of Bercon’s terms. The specific rate, overburden ratio and drilling provisions were examined to determine if they formed part of a complete and enforceable agreement.
sections.conclusion: The court concluded that a binding contract had been formed between the parties based on the 18 May 1992 letter and Grand Mines’ subsequent conduct, and it upheld the agreed rate of R14.00 per ROM ton, ordering the parties to perform according to those terms.
